metadata.title: The home cloud revolution: how to host your personal cloud from home. | by Simone Aronica | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: The home cloud revolution: how to host your personal cloud from home.
metadata.description: Google tracks you. Yes, I know it is not a shock to read, but that’s true. Well, yes, pretty much every big company tracks you, but you probably don’t know how much Google is active on the web…

all_paragraphs: Google tracks you. Yes, I know it is not a shock to read, but that’s true. Well, yes, pretty much every big company tracks you, but you probably don’t know how much Google is active on the web. Quoting this article from Duck Duck Go:
Princeton’s WebTAP privacy project recently found that Google’s trackers are installed on 75% of the top million Internet websites.

I’ve been gradually shifting away from Google’s ecosystem, and while it’s almost impossible to not use any of Google’s many apps, in this article I’ll show you how to get rid of one of Google’s most popular services: Google Drive.

Be aware that this article will show you how to host a cloud application at home, and it won’t be exactly cheap. The approximate cost of this setup when buying from OEM is €130 or $159, but obviously, you can cut down the prices by buying from third parties.

A little warning here: hosting a cloud yourself is not as safe as having someone host it. It’s riskier as any accident such as a power outage or overload could fry your devices and you’d basically lose all your files. If you’re afraid of this, use a UPS and a RAID Backup over multiple drives.
Also, you will need a public static IP for your network, so if you intend to follow along and install Nextcloud, contact your ISP to request it.

Nextcloud is a cloud platform that you can self-host. Self-hosting is what allows you to regain control of your data, the documents, pictures, and everything else that you will upload won’t be uploaded to Google’s or Microsoft’s servers, but to your personal server.

Also, it is an open-source project, which means that every single line of code that it relies on can be and is checked from the community. When the source code is available, you can literally read everything that happens to your files. No more not knowing what happens to your data.
You can find more information on the official website.

The most important tool that we’ll find throughout these guides is the Raspberry Pi, in our case in the iteration 4B 2GB that you can buy from raspberrypi.org. The website does not allow you to buy the board from OEM but instead redirects you towards its partnered shops available in your country.

You must use a dedicated RaspberryPi 4B for this project to avoid overheating. My Raspberry Pi 3 easily got to 158 degrees Fahrenheit or 70 degrees celsius just from running Nextcloud and a few other web projects.

The second piece of hardware we’ll need is a case for the Raspberry Pi. The case that I recommend is the PiCase 40, which should be available in the common market starting from mid-September 2020, once it leaves Kickstarter. You can use any compatible case, or even don’t use any at all, but this particular piece from Cooler Master should ensure that your device doesn’t overheat too often.

We’ll have to flash the system to a microSD storage, so we need to buy one. I’d recommend a reliable SD such as the Samsung EVO 32GB that you can find on Samsung’s website, but really any 16GB+ memory will do, we’ll only use it for the OS and Nextcloud’s database.
If you have a laptop that can read SD Cards you’re lucky, but if you don’t you’ll need to buy a MicroSD to USB adapter. You can find it both online and in most electronics stores.
To store the data, I recommend using a USB Drive, Hard Drive or SSD. What I think that suits best is the up to 5TBs Seagate Basic that you can buy from Walmart or most online electronics stores.
Lastly, you’ll need a 5V 3A power supply with a USB Type-C connector. If you’re unsure of what or where to buy, this is the official power supply from the Raspberry Foundation.
You’ll also need an ethernet cable, but since we’re talking about networking I should not even be mentioning that.
If you’re a power user or you’ve already worked on a Raspberry Pi you can flash Raspberry Pi OS Lite and skip this section.
If you’re a normal user and you’ve never touched a Raspberry Pi, you’re up for a great journey!

Now first things first you’ll need to insert the Raspberry Pi into your case. If you’ve bought the PiCase 40 you can watch this video to mount the board into the case, though it should be pretty straightforward.

To flash the OS to the MicroSD you have to connect it to the PC either directly if you can or via the adaptor, and then download the Raspberry Pi Imager. If you’re on Linux you can install it via this command:

Open the imager, choose the SD and install not Ubuntu but Raspberry Pi OS Lite via Raspberry Pi OS (Other)— we could also install Ubuntu and use snap to install Nextcloud or directly install the system image of NextCloudPi, but in this guide, we’ll be using Raspberry Pi OS.

To use the Raspberry Pi you can either connect via ssh or use it directly connecting it to a USB keyboard and an HDMI monitor. I’ll use SSH, therefore, you can skip the next step if you will connect it directly.

Once the flash is finished use your file manager to navigate to the SD Card and create a file in the root directory called ssh — not ssh.txt, just ssh, if you’re on Windows you can use the top bar to enable the extensions via the menu View > File extensions.
Eject the card and then insert it into the card slot on the board. Good, our Raspberry Pi is now ready to be booted up. Plug it into the wall mount and connect it to your router.

Now, this is a bit tricky, you’ll need to enter your router’s page to check out the IP Address of the raspberry pi. Unfortunately, I cannot provide better details as every manufacturer has different landing pages. What I can do is tell you that usually, the IP of the router is 192.168.x.1, 192.168.x.254, where x can be either 0 or 1. You can easily find if you must set 0 or 1 via the terminal of your computer, running the command
if you’re on Linux and looking at your computer’s IP.
Similar steps can be taken if you’re running Mac OS, as Mac OS is based on Unix just like Linux.
Now that the Raspberry Pi is setup we need to connect to it via the command line using SSH. Usually, both Windows and Mac come with an SSH client, so just boot up your terminal and run:

where pi is the default user of the Raspberry Pi and ip_address must be replaced with the IP of your Raspberry. The default password of the pi account is raspberry, though I advise you to change it once logged in with the command
Now to install Nextcloud you simply need to run the command:
and if for some reason you don’t have curl automatically installed, just run

For the next step, navigate to HTTP://rpi-ip-address, where rpi-ip-address is the IP of your Raspberry Pi, and save the passwords that will be given to you. The default user is ncp, so you don’t need to save it as it’s not randomized. Click on “activate” and a new page will be opened in your browser prompting you for a username and a password. Set ncp as username and the password you’ve saved as password.
Now the fun begins, you’re entering Nextcloud’s portal, and you will be asked to start the setup wizard:
Follow the simplified wizard and when asked whether you want to be able to access Nextcloud from outside your house, click on yes.

If you’re not sure of how to port-forward an application, tell Nextcloud to try and do it for you. It will use the UPnP standard to try and set up the port forwarding automatically. However, we will also cover how to port-forward an application later.

The next step is a bit tricky. Now, to make your server available from outside your house you might want to set up a domain, which means that instead of using 2.210.123.43 to enter your server, you will simply use something like thisismynextcloudserver.com. Now you don’t really need a .com, any domain will do. You can use Namecheap to buy really cheap .me domains (I got mine at something around $2).

If you don’t want to buy a domain you can use services like the ones that will be recommended to you by Nextcloud, which basically create a subdomain for each account, so you’d probably have something similar to yourname.freedns.com.
I recommend you buy a domain yourself which is what I’ll be showing you in this guide. Select Skip and finish your setup.

Now currently our web server is running on HTTP, which means that the data exchanged between the device and the server is not encrypted. You don’t want your data to be online unencrypted, so let’s install a certificate. For this, you’ll need to buy a domain.
Go to whatsymip.org and save somewhere your IP, we’ll need it later.
Create an account on namecheap.com or really any other domain name provider that you trust and buy your domain.

Then, if you’ve used namecheap, go to your domains and click on manage at the right of your domain to reveal the advanced information tab. Now click on advanced dns — or simply navigate to ap.www.namecheap.com/Domains/DomainControlPanel/yourdomain/advancedns — and add an A Record with Host @ and value your IP. Then add a CNAME record with host www and value yourdomain.
In the end, your configuration should include these two records:
What we’re doing is telling the domain that when visited it should point towards your IP from both yourdomain and www.yourdomain.
Then go back to your terminal and install certbot:
In this step we’ll retrieve the certificates that will be used to encrypt the connection, so run:
This is how you should configure it:
Finally, go back to HTTP://rpi-ip-address:1443 into the control panel and add yourdomain and www.yourdomain to the section nc-trusted-domains section.
First, we need to format the USB to btrfs, but don’t worry, it’s not hard. Connect the drive to the raspberry pi and unplug every other drive. Then run:
and navigate to tools > nc-format-USB:

Follow the on-screen procedure to format the USB Drive and then press exit to go back to the main page. It’s important that you remember the name of the drive after this step or leave the default name.
Now navigate to system > nc-automount, follow the setup procedure and when on this screen, replace no with yes:
Finally, navigate to config > nc-datadir and change the data directory to /media/yourdevicename or, if you’ve used the default name /media/MyCloudDrive.

Now we are pretty much finished. We only need to set up the port forwarding. For this, you need to go back to your modem’s page like in the first steps and find a section called Port Forwarding or Port Mapping. Port mapping is basically mapping your modem to make certain ports available outside of your network, so that when you go to yourip:port, the service will be available across the internet. In the new port mapping you’ll have to add a TCP exception towards your raspberry pi’s IP along with the port 443 both as internal and external port. Do the same for port 80.
Good, we are basically done. Test that everything is working by heading to yourdomain. You should be greeted with a similar page:
This means that you are now ready to use nextcloud. You can login with the username ncp using the password you’ve saved earlier.
As you can see, you can now access all your files across the internet safely. You can also download the app for android and iOS and setup a photo backup as you would do in google photos.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Hi, I’m Simone, a computer engineering student in Turin. I think technology is the future, and everyone should have the right to know how it works.
